repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Inspired by #3780, this is my first attempt accelerating divmod() in Cython by calling (pure) C div() function for C int type integers.

If this is expected, I could subsequently open another PR for C long type integers by calling (pure) C ldiv() function.

Do I need to append the div() function as the C API equivalent in the docs/src/userguide/language_basics.rst file?

comment_data.body: I don't understand this line. Why not just return `args`?
`nogil=True` seems dodgy for something that returns a Python tuple.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -160,6 +160,9 @@ def declare_in_type(self, self_type):
     #('compile',   "",     "",      ""), # PyObject* Py_CompileString(    char *str, char *filename, int start)
     BuiltinFunction('delattr',    "OO",   "r",     "PyObject_DelAttr"),
     BuiltinFunction('dir',        "O",    "O",     "PyObject_Dir"),
+    BuiltinFunction('divmod',     "ii",   "O",     "__Pyx_divmod_int",
+                    utility_code=UtilityCode.load("divmod_int", "Builtins.c"),
+                    is_strict_signature = True, nogil = True),

comment_data.body: Also don't think this is right - `PyTuple_Pack` takes `PyObject*` and you're passing it C `int`
Oh, I mistakenly thought PyTuple_Pack() passes C arguments. Looks like I need to modify that to Py_BuildValue("(ii)", res.quot, res.rem).

Why `int` and not `long`?
You can also define multiple variants using the different C types and corresponding functions:
https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/numeric/math/div
See the `abs()` implementation in this file (`Builtins.py`).
Removed in the second commit, please review. Thank you.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -160,6 +160,9 @@ def declare_in_type(self, self_type):
     #('compile',   "",     "",      ""), # PyObject* Py_CompileString(    char *str, char *filename, int start)
     BuiltinFunction('delattr',    "OO",   "r",     "PyObject_DelAttr"),
     BuiltinFunction('dir',        "O",    "O",     "PyObject_Dir"),
+    BuiltinFunction('divmod',     "ii",   "O",     "__Pyx_divmod_int",
+                    utility_code=UtilityCode.load("divmod_int", "Builtins.c"),
+                    is_strict_signature = True, nogil = True),

comment_data.body:
This should really return a ctuple `(int, int)` instead of a Python tuple. Can't say how difficult that would be to set up and implement. ctuples are implemented as C structs, so you need a struct type declaration. See the `abs` implementations for a way to declare the exact function type, including its return type.

Not necessarily something for this PR. It would also make the exception handling difficult.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -160,6 +160,9 @@ def declare_in_type(self, self_type):
     #('compile',   "",     "",      ""), # PyObject* Py_CompileString(    char *str, char *filename, int start)
     BuiltinFunction('delattr',    "OO",   "r",     "PyObject_DelAttr"),
     BuiltinFunction('dir',        "O",    "O",     "PyObject_Dir"),
+    BuiltinFunction('divmod',     "ii",   "O",     "__Pyx_divmod_int",
+                    utility_code=UtilityCode.load("divmod_int", "Builtins.c"),
+                    is_strict_signature = True),

comment_data.body:
We should probably check (with a tree assertion) that this uses the right utility function, i.e. that the optimisation was actually applied.

EDIT: better do this in the dedicated new test file than this generic one.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,9 +7,11 @@ cdef int f() except -1:
     cdef int i
     cdef long lng
     cdef Py_ssize_t s
+    cdef int f = 0, g = 1
     x = abs(y)
     delattr(x, 'spam')
     x = dir(y)
+    x = divmod(f, g)

comment_data.body: I'd suggest probably doing `PyLong_FromLong` on res.quot and res.rem rather than `Py_BuildValue` - parsing the string isn't likely to be hugely quick and we are trying to make this an optimization.
Replaced by `Py_BuildValue` at the second commit.
Switched to it in the third commit, please review. Thank you.
As stated in the top, I was planning like if expanding to C div() function is accepted, I could subsequently open another PR for C long type integers by calling (pure) C ldiv() function.
Implemented in the tests/run/builtin_divmod.pyx file from the third commit.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,9 +7,11 @@ cdef int f() except -1:
     cdef int i
     cdef long lng
     cdef Py_ssize_t s
+    cdef int f = 0, g = 1
     x = abs(y)
     delattr(x, 'spam')
     x = dir(y)
+    x = divmod(f, g)

comment_data.body: Done in the fourth commit.
Both PyLong creation calls need error handling before calling other C-API functions.
Fine with me. You can then probably use simple code generation for the three different C integer types to avoid duplicating the implementation.

Here, the error handling is redundant.
```suggestion
        return result_tuple;
```
It would be better to have this conversion code only once.

It would be great to get direct comparison with Python's implementation here. You can rename the file to `.py`, use `import cython` in it, and then apply the type declarations as `a: cython.int` etc. to keep everything in Python syntax.
Handled in the latest commit. Please review it. Thank you.
Removed in the latest commit. Please review it. Thank you.
Refactored in the latest commit. Please review it. Thank you.
Adopted in the latest commit. Please review it. Thank you.

commit.message: Accelerate divmod() by calling C div() for C int type integers.
Use Py_BuildValue to pass C arguments, along with other suggested fixes.
Handle the inconsistency between Python and C on calculating quotients and remainders when the dividend is negative and the divisor is positive and vice versa.
Handle the division by zero case.
Refactor the calculation code and utilise .py file for testing.
Avoid leaking references, fix doc typo
